Or it so happens that technologically, scientists have invented a new customs technology, the technology of deductible duties, deductible by the exporter from the importing State’s economy.
Concretely, this deductable customs duty is transformed into a customs credit equal to the amount of the customs duty borne by the exporter in the importing country.
This customs credit has three characteristics: it is refundable, negotiable, and bonus-eligible.
It is refundable at the moment the exporter purchases from the importer; he can deduct the customs duty he has borne.

It is negotiable because if the exporting company that has borne the center of customs duties has nothing to purchase from the importer, it negotiates its customs credit on the stock market or with a bank.
And it is eligible for enhancement if we wish to assist developing countries by enabling the importer to offer a customs credit amount exceeding the amount of customs duties.
Well, with this technique, we create an international currency of exchange whose monetary mass is equal to the amount of existing customs duties.

I believe that in our time, when public opinion is increasingly sensitized—justifiably so—regarding the welfare of animals, whether concerning rearing conditions, slaughtering practices, or transportation, states must respect these sentiments.
Since I am given the floor, I would like to add, concerning transportation, that it would be essential to consider, independently of transport durations, the local climatic conditions.
Indeed, a several-hour transport carried out in the Netherlands in springtime is nothing comparable to the same transport time in full summer in a country such as Greece.
Should night-time transport services not be mandated in these latter cases?

This report manages to reconcile the right to information, while strictly defining the nutritional elements that must compulsorily appear on labels, and the right to intellectual property, which is so important for preserving the competitiveness of our industries.

I believe that, indeed, manufacturers should be obligated to immediately notify the use of any new raw materials entering into the composition of animal feed, in order to guarantee transparency and to facilitate the control carried out by the competent authorities.
Including an emergency procedure that allows for the introduction of a new hazardous substance into the list of prohibited materials seems entirely indispensable to me.

Similarly, providing the breeder with the possibility of questioning the competent national authority or the European Commission in cases of doubt regarding a misleading claim allows for better verification of systems, both to protect the consumer and to preserve the fairness of commercial transactions.

I therefore wish to offer my full support to this excellent report, because experience shows that regulation of pet food labeling—I conclude, Mr. President—prioritizing quality, transparency, traceability, and control is the best guarantee to prevent further failings in Europe.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I regret that the Council and the Commission have yet to undertake a concrete definition of territorial cohesion.
The French Presidency is being tested there, and I wish to commend this initiative.
Our Parliament continues to insist that this objective be applicable from the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty and that its contours be clarified as soon as possible.

I wish, in the manner of the excellent report by Mr. Van Nistelroy, that territorial cohesion should become the legal basis, guaranteeing the harmonious development of all territories of the Union and enabling us to make the best possible use of the specific characteristics of each European region.
It is essential to better coordinate community policies in order to maximize the impact of interventions on the ground.
Territorial cohesion is not intended to target exclusively regions experiencing permanent disadvantages.
It must nevertheless focus on the polycentric development of the European Union as a whole, taking into account the characteristics of each territory while preserving their diversity.
This new concept appears relevant for taking into account the outermost regions, to ensure their sustainable and balanced growth.

In this regard, I thank the rapporteur for having incorporated in these compromise amendments my requests concerning the specific challenges faced by outermost regions in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, essential components of territorial cohesion.

recommendations for improving governance in cohesion matters, thereby making RUPS the first illustration, somewhat anticipated, of the implementation of territorial cohesion.

I hope that the Overseas General Assembly, which will soon commence in France, proceeds in the same manner and comprehensively integrates the major territorial impact of European policies aimed at streets whose added value is undeniable.

Madam President, I believe that, indeed, the issue of distributing food supplies to benefit the most vulnerable is entirely timely, but I believe that, fundamentally, the Commission’s proposal does not address the problem.
Sir, the question of co-financing troubles me, and I believe the issue is rather the question of liberalism that has guided our evaluations of the CAP in recent years that needs to be challenged.
Riots against hunger and the sudden fluctuations in food prices are enduring indicators of the limitations of agricultural market liberalization.
This liberalization has always come at the expense of vulnerable populations, vulnerable producers, and vulnerable territories.

I therefore argue that policy should reclaim its rightful place, regain control at both the European and global levels, and that the strategic domain of agriculture and food provision for people, both in terms of quantity and quality, should not be subjected to the strict laws of the market.
Certainly, there is a sense of urgency, and the Sigerski report addresses this urgency, which I welcome, but I wish that, within the framework of the reflection that is opening on the
Regarding its coming from the CAP, it should be recalled that the primary objective is indeed to structurally combat hunger and poverty as we know them in all Member States and worldwide.
Rural territories are available to meet food needs through sufficient and quality productions. Yet, will they be given the financial and human resources to assume this heavy responsibility?
Mr. President, in this period of economic recession, it was important that the European Union continue to demonstrate its solidarity with developing countries.
Let us recall that in 2007, the European Community and the Member States together contributed 60% of total development assistance, making the European Union the world’s leading donor.
European Development Funds contribute to the fight against poverty, while promoting economic development and democracy.

I am therefore pleased that for CPp countries, a budget of twenty-three billion euros was allocated for the period 2008-2013 under the tenth FED, representing practically double the amount foreseen for the ninth FED.
The reconciliation of accounts in its report concluded that the accounts of the seventh, eighth, and ninth Fed are, in general, true, lawful, and regular.
One can only welcome the record levels of contract execution and implementation payments for the Funds.
However, I also observe that progress must be continued to strengthen the control and monitoring system, as a significant level of errors affecting certain transactions still exists.
Similarly, there is a risk level often exaggerated in budgetary support matters, and it is, in my opinion, advisable to better assess these risks.
On this matter, I share the view that budget support should be provided only if the beneficiary country has the capacity to manage funds transparently, responsibly, and effectively.

Among the priorities on which we must work in the future, I would like to mention the integration of community considerations into the general budget, as I am concluding my term. This would strengthen the effectiveness and transparency of development aid.

To conclude, Mr. President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, the representatives of the Court, but also all the staff of the Commission, who did an excellent job on site, and I obviously regret the absence of the Council and, in particular, the Czech Presidency.

Madam President, we cannot remain silent on the situation in Madagascar, and we will not be alone in condemning it.
The African Union, the Southern African Development Community, the International Organization of La Francophonie, the Inter-Parliamentary Union, the European Union at the word of the Commission, the

A large number of countries, including the United States and Norway—to speak of countries on the European continent—have condemned the coup d'état because one must call a spade a spade, even if it occurred in Madagascar.
We cannot remain silent and we demand a return to constitutional legality.
We never request a return to the starting point, with, if necessary, an arbitration by the Malagasy people through a consultation in the form of a presidential election or referendum.
It is incumbent upon the assemblies and political leaders of Madagascar to determine the most effective form of consultation.
What we are requesting with this joint resolution is to add our voice to that of the international community to clearly signal to those who have seized power in a wholly

democratic and in the form of a coup d'état, however cleverly disguised it may be, to return to Madagascar's constitutional legality, which is one of the guarantors of the future development of this large island in the Indian Ocean.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, naturally, I would like to thank Commissioner Dimas for his presence and responses, and for the continued attention he gives to all these disasters.
We worked together extensively when President Barroso asked me to prepare a report, which he subsequently cited, on the creation of a European civil protection force.
I presented this report on May 9, 2006.
When I reread it and see all the catastrophes that have occurred, I find myself thinking that it remains perpetually relevant.
Mr. and Mrs. Zavela, of course, there is more than just Greece.
All countries are affected, and I would add that there are not only natural disasters, but also human disasters caused by humans.
I think of maritime disasters, the Erika and how many others, and industrial accidents of the Chernobyl type.
There are other natural disasters besides wildfires.
I am thinking about the tsunami.
We may one day fear a tsunami in the Mediterranean, as there was one at the beginning of the 20th century that utterly destroyed the city of Messina.
Frankly, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the tools we deploy are not up to the scale of these catastrophes that are going to multiply due to both global warming and transportation.
That is why I believe we need to be more ambitious.
I thank the Commission, Commissioner Dimas, all of their teams, and the Directorate-General, for operating the civil protection mechanism.
I believe that we must go further.
With member states wishing to do so, enhanced cooperation can be envisioned.
If we are not twenty-seven to form this civil protection unit, let us start with twelve or fifteen.
And then you will see that it will concern everyone.
When I make a list of catastrophes, I can say that everyone is affected: the floods that struck Germany in 2002, and even major pandemics, as well as terrorism.
Here, Monsieur le Commissaire, is why I would wish the Commission to take the initiative, to propose to the Member States that they go further.
Our Parliament, the Environment Committee, and the Defence and Security Committee will support you in these voluntary initiatives.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen Deputies, once again this summer the Mediterranean forest has been ravaged by flames in Marseille, in Southern Corsica, but also in Italy, in Spain, and on a larger scale in Greece.
More than 400 hectares of forests and fields have been consumed by fire, triggering considerable material debates, irreversible damage to biodiversity, and dramatic losses of human life.
Deeply dismayed by this recurring annual toll and aware of the multiplier effect of global warming on fires.
I call for a European awareness-raising initiative to improve coordination of efforts and to pool resources for firefighting.
I wish to see the realization of an extensive Euro-Mediterranean cooperation project to combat forest fires within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean.
I commend the existing initiatives, and notably the European Forest Fire Information System, pilot project.
Nevertheless, I advocate for a reform of the European Union's Solidarity Fund so that it becomes a robust tool for responding to crises and a strengthening of European resilience.
and of the mechanism devised by Michel Barnier from 2006 onwards to intervene in the territory of the twenty-seven member states as well as abroad.

I believe that one of the keys to the problem of forest fires lies in the exchange of knowledge and good practices concerning prevention, and I would like to highlight the pioneering role played by foresters—particularly in my own department.
I can readily make this example available to Europe, which may prove useful.

Mr. President, my contribution concerns the deterioration of working conditions in Europe.

In Europe, the number of working poor is increasing day by day, and the International Labour Organization counts sixty deaths annually attributable to a lack of prevention.
In this context, I would like to emphasize our responsibility toward all those who are deprived of employment and social rights, who work under undignified conditions.
of these millions of workers who suffer morally and physically, sometimes driven to suicide or victims of cancer or chronic illnesses due to their working conditions.

the right to decent work and strengthening the right to work must be at the top of the Union’s priorities within the next ten years
Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, we face a challenge for humanity, a challenge for future generations.

To achieve the Gt target, Copenhagen must allow for a global agreement, a single agreement, as our committee chair for the environment, Joaoui, specified earlier, a coalition of all—industrialized nations, emerging nations, and essential.

Today, with our debate and also the drafting of a resolution by our Parliament, we once again call on the European Union to maintain its leading role in this necessary policy of combating climate change.
Let us recall that it is fitting that we speak with a single voice to maintain our credibility.
Or, we must arrive at an agreement in Copenhagen to limit the increase in global average temperature to a level that does not exceed two degrees above pre-industrial levels.
Yes, we must in Copenhagen sign an agreement to achieve collective emissions reductions of thirty percent by 2020 compared to 1990.
But that will not be altered.
ideas not only necessary for developed countries to significantly reduce their emissions, but also that developing countries contribute to achieving the goals.

Industrialized countries must, therefore, provide sufficient, sustained, and predictable financial and technical support to developing countries to encourage them to commit to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions.
Copenhagen must therefore enable developing countries to transition towards low-carbon models.
Also, allow me to address two avenues that seem necessary for our future.
First, the global establishment of climate change mitigation funding based on the taxation of financial transactions.

Subsequently, it appears necessary to implement a fiscal adjustment at the borders of Europe that will apply after the importation of products manufactured without any regard for environmental protection. Fiscal adjustment related to

contractualization and transfer to Southern countries of the carbon tax collected at the borders of Europe, which would serve to finance investments in the equipment necessary for their fight against global warming.

Mr. President, I would like to speak along the same lines as my intervention yesterday regarding the preparation for the Copenhagen summit, and following the ecofin meeting yesterday, which, incidentally, was not a success.
I was addressing you regarding the responsibility we have, as industrialized nations, to ensure that developing countries can keep pace with our efforts to combat climate change.
In Copenhagen, we cannot pretend that we all have the same capabilities; otherwise, it would mean that we are all starting from the same point to ultimately achieve nothing.
To convince our development partners to join us, it will be essential to address the question of the assistance that must be provided to them and not wait for the outcome of the Copenhagen summit.
During the upcoming European Council, the twenty-seven must absolutely agree on how the European Union views aid to developing countries within the significant context of climate change.
Yesterday, therefore, as I was saying, the ECOFIN Council failed to find a common position on this issue.
Yet, we know that this question is absolutely central.
The European Commission has already put forward proposals. I absolutely want us to take the lead in guiding our partners towards a global solidarity necessary to overcome this climate change problem.
the efforts of the Swedish Presidency to achieve an ambitious agreement in Copenhagen, and this, despite the very strong wind of pessimism blowing over its future negotiations.
For my part, I believe it is not realistic to concede at this stage that the Copenhagen summit is a lost cause or that it will not result in a conclusive agreement ratified by all parties.
Let us not yield too quickly to pessimism.
I advocate that at this stage, we do not scale back our ambitions, neither in terms of objectives nor in terms of deadlines.
We must continue to believe in a global, comprehensive, ambitious, and binding political agreement, paving the way for the conclusion of a legally binding treaty as soon as possible.
It is truly too early to discuss the deadline of the COP 16 of December two thousand ten.
We must now translate our rhetoric into genuine political will.
We must clarify our commitment in terms of financial resources and assistance to developing countries, particularly concerning technology transfers.
At this stage, a total and collective commitment from the European Union is indispensable.

I also note on paper the recent, yet exemplary, commitments made—or to speak specifically of Brazil, South Korea, Indonesia, and Norway, among others—which have quantified their ambitions to reduce their polluting emissions.

If we can understand the flexibility sought by the United States, which is only beginning to consider the climate question, we will nevertheless need to reach binding and ambitious quantified commitments in the short, medium, and long term from other major polluters like the United States and China.
Lacking alternatives, we head toward climatic, political, and moral disaster.
Madam President, we all know and we have all said the importance of the Copenhagen negotiations, but if we all hope for an agreement, we cannot accept an agreement at any price.
If the conditions for an ambitious agreement are not met, I wish to state very clearly that the European Union must be able to say no and refuse to sign a watered-down agreement.
The European populations that we represent here expect an agreement, an agreement that will allow us to effectively combat all of the climatic disruptions we observe daily around us.
They will not settle for mere publicity stunts, unquantified statements of intent, or non-binding objectives upon which it will be possible to simply walk away once the media spotlight has faded.

In Copenhagen, states will have to commit. The European Union, the only continent to have seen its CO2 emissions decrease since 1910, and the only one to foresee specific, binding, and ambitious commitments for the future, cannot shoulder the burden alone.

That is why, if other industrialized and emerging countries do not wish to assume their share of the burden, we will need to draw all the consequences by establishing at our borders a tax protecting our industry from competition from those who decide not to participate in a global agreement.
We Europeans demand a little more each day from our industrialists.
I would like proof of this in the climate package that was signed under French presidency.

I would like proof of this in national initiatives which, like the carbon tax, praised just now by Mr. Pargnot—and I commend this—these national initiatives promote the establishment of an ecological taxation system.

A sector such as transportation, which is among the largest emitters of CO2—even if certain modes of transport like aviation emit fewer greenhouse gases—is increasingly contributing to the fight against climate change.
This is a sector that has been severely impacted by the aftermath of the crisis.

If, as I hope, maritime and air transport are integrated into the negotiations in Copenhagen, then let us ensure that what will be asked of European industries will also be asked of those in other industrialized countries.
In Copenhagen, global public opinion will have all eyes on the decision-makers. Please conclude, if you please. Do not disappoint us. Thank you.
Madam President, dear colleagues, the Copenhagen summit is a historic opportunity to change the course of the planet.
We must strive to reach decisions even more binding than those adopted in Kyoto.
We too must call on our leaders to create an international organization, such as the WTO, responsible for regulating climate change and environmental issues, and to create a
In addition to, of course, public development aid, to create a maritime and aviation carbon tax, as we must also do on financial transactions.
We clearly see the pressing need for global regulation of the environment, as well as that of financial markets and the Internet.
We have the opportunity to open this margin of history through the environment.
Let us do so in the image of our highest human inspirations, failing which we will appear as those responsible, without any grasp of the realities of things. I thank you.

Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, dear colleagues, less than two weeks before the Copenhagen conference, concerns are mounting regarding the success of climate change negotiations.
Some, indeed, already say that it will be a failure.
Major global powers still hesitate to demonstrate the full ambition that the climate emergency demands of them.

By adopting the resolution tomorrow on the European Union’s strategy ahead of the Copenhagen Conference, we, Members of the European Parliament, must demonstrate that our determination is first and foremost absolute, and that the Conference must result in an agreement that is certainly precise, but above all legally binding.
Furthermore, the binding nature of this agreement, which will be reached, must not be called into question or challenged.

We cannot indefinitely postpone the decision to tomorrow, lest it be too late; hence the necessary creation of a global environmental organization, which appears today not only necessary but also urgent, since it will, under the auspices of the UN, be responsible for overseeing the implementation of commitments made in Copenhagen.
From Copenhagen onwards, we must expect greater engagement and responsibility from the world’s leading minds.

We must now go further by pooling our resources and organizing joint return flights funded by Frontex.

The decision of the twenty-seven to request from the Commission a study on this subject is a first step, and Mr. Commissioner, I wish the Commission to support this proposal, as the fight against immigration and illegality is an expectation of public opinion and, particularly, of immigrant populations in regular status.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, dear colleagues, the importance of the climate change issue is no longer in question.

These impacts, whether short, medium, or long term, are undeniable, even if today, the results of the GEC are featured on the front page of a national newspaper and certainly reinforce the positions of skeptics.
The Copenhagen summit appeared to the world as a unique opportunity for world leaders to acknowledge, act upon, and rectify the effects of climate change.

The European Union was at the forefront of this discussion, not only due to the pioneering legislation that we have in place regarding the limitation of the impact of our activities on the climate, but also because Europe represents a union of countries that can truly make a difference.
Certainly, the outcome of the Copenhagen conference can only leave a feeling of dissatisfaction, but I refuse to speak of failure.
The world has agreed on the issue of limiting temperature increases to 2 degrees, even for a country as reluctant as China.
Brazil has just enacted a law aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by nearly thirty-nine percent by 2030, in accordance with its commitments.
Many others have also demonstrated considerable ambition regarding greenhouse gas emission reduction targets.
I am thinking of Japan and Norway.
Furthermore, it is also important to highlight this very positive point, which was the consensus reached regarding the urgency of a mechanism for reducing emissions due to deforestation.
A specific and unanimous text was obtained regarding the implementation of the 'I mechanism' to reduce deforestation and thereby enable natural CO2 storage.
Far from a binding agreement, but clearly in line with a political accord, the outcome of Copenhagen should lead us to question the reasons for such disappointment.
I attended the Copenhagen Conference, as did many of my colleagues, with the desire to participate, to help, and to witness a negotiating Europe, a leading Europe.
My disappointment was significant, as Europe clearly did not have the place it deserved in the negotiations, and even more so when it came to the European Parliament.
To assert itself, Europe must demonstrate greater strength on the matter.
The meeting of our ministers on the environment in Seville did not yield results, and our representatives proved uncertain, hesitant, and we remain divided on our objectives.
I hope that Ms. Hedegard, bolstered by her proposals and commitments made before the Environment Committee, will be able to raise the ambitions of the European Union.

I now give the floor to my dear colleagues. To escape the caricatures—we have heard a few this morning—I would like to recall some objective elements concerning Tunisia, a partner country of the European Union.

The social situation has evolved very favorably, with a spectacular increase in average income per capita, and now, the vast majority of Tunisians meet the criteria defining membership in the middle class.

More than four hundred and eighty Tunisian citizens benefit from social security, and over a quarter of Tunisia’s budget is allocated to education, meaning that the country is among the first to have achieved the Millennium Development Goals regarding primary education.
Finally, as Michel mentioned just now, women’s rights are recognized and guaranteed.
At the university, female students outnumber male students, and 40% of the professors are women. A quarter of the members of parliament, local elected officials, or journalists are women.
Many countries could envy such results.

Mr. President, less than 15% of the original red ethn stock remains today.
Faced with such figures, the solution appears obvious.
Nevertheless, it is important not to overlook the positions affected by the decisions that concern us today.
It must be recalled that the city is not tasked with prohibiting fishing but only the international trade of this fish, eighty percent of which is exported to Japan.

By maintaining the tone, we are certainly protecting a dangerously coveted species, but we are also encouraging the continuation of a more balanced, more sustainable fishing activity—a fishery destined for our domestic market and a source of employment.

I am in favor of the inclusion of the red zone in Annex I of the CITité. While I believe this decision will be positive, I require the Commission’s assistance to allow for a profound restructuring of the fishing sector.
My question therefore concerns the modalities of this support.
France requests a suspension of eighteen months, accompanied by financial measures for seafarers and shipowners affected by a trade ban.
