Furthermore, my concern—as is the case for many of my colleagues—centers on equity.
How can we ensure that vessels flying the flags of countries like Tunisia, Libya, or others will apply the ban on international trade with a rigor comparable to our own?
What will the new measures of control and sanctions be?

The sustainability policy for our economic activities must be concrete, sometimes even unpopular in certain sectors, but I hope that the Commission and the Council do not lose sight of the adjustments necessary for the implementation of these measures.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, as the rapporteur has reported, this draft directive indeed follows a vote in Parliament, as you also recalled, Mr. Commissioner.
However, my group remains extremely critical of this proposal because it risks backfiring on those we seek to support.
In seeking to lighten the burden on businesses, we risk depriving them of the conditions of transparency and trust essential to their management and the dynamism of their operations.
First, I believe it’s important to be clear about thresholds and what is termed a microentity.
These are SMEs with more than ten employees and an annual turnover of over one million euros.
Regardless of the member state, this represents a very large majority of companies.
Certainly, they may be local and have limited presence in the community market. However, the necessity of presenting accounting rules will not be abolished for them, and that
Accounting rules will confront them each time they wish to deal with a bank, with partners, or negotiate occasionally with fiscal, economic, and social institutions.
At that point, accounting rules will be imposed upon them, and they may have to pay more than they would for standard accounting in order to meet criteria they may not necessarily understand.
I do not see any benefit in imposing accounting requirements beyond those common to the European Union.
This is not simply a matter of competition. It is fundamentally a question of economic integration, of community law, and of equal treatment for all businesses within the European Union.
That being said, it is, of course, a necessity to simplify accounting obligations for SMEs.
Three initiatives, moreover, are moving in that direction, whether it be the proposal we are discussing today, or the IF international framework.
LRS, whether it be the revision of the fourth and seventh accounting directives for which the European Commission should shortly be submitting proposals to us.
These proposals were promised to us for 2010; it appears they are being extended, but I do not believe this extension of the deadline is a sufficient reason for this.
to rush and do a half-hearted job, for these three proposals, or if they share the same objective, may not have the same articulation. It seems to me, Mr. Commissioner.

is clearer for businesses to provide them with a single, comprehensive response that will allow them to reconcile the objective of simplifying obligations, desired by all, with the practical realities of life for small businesses that need it.
The current problem is that the European Commission is dragging its feet in proposing a revision of these directives, and this is detrimental to our deliberations.

I therefore urge the European Commission to accelerate the dialogue on the issue of exemption, which is currently dividing both European institutions and economic circles, and to undertake an impact assessment.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and my dear colleagues, as my colleague Elisabeth Morin-Chartier and other colleagues have indicated, on February twenty-seventh and twenty-eighth, the violent storm Cynthia struck several French regions, resulting in fifty-three fatalities and substantial material damage.
The storm was of exceptional intensity, causing devastating floods along the French coastline.
Following Maire, Europe is once again involved.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadec, has been severely affected.
Three French departments have thus been declared as disaster areas: Brittany, Poitou-Charente, and the Loire Valley.
Faced with these disasters, the European Union must demonstrate its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not only through words and a resolution, but also and above all through financial assistance that we will be able to support the victims of these disasters.

Therefore, I invite, and my colleague Christophe Bechus joins me in this initiative, as the European Commission has swiftly released the Union Solidarity Fund to assist affected regions in coping with the damages.
This disaster demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier’s proposal to create a European civil intervention force.

Europeans must act collectively, as disasters multiply and affect our European territories, particularly our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I would also like to congratulate our rapporteur, Jörg Leirid, on his report and his spirit of cooperation in this dossier, and I particularly support what concerns his proposals on the funding of aviation security, since we are speaking here of aviation security and not air safety.

It has been many years that our Commission has been fighting to have the principle accepted that stricter safety measures must be borne by the Member States, and I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, security does not concern only travelers, but all citizens, and it is the responsibility of states to take measures to combat terrorism.
It is therefore not justified that air passengers alone should bear the burden of financing security measures in airports and on board aircraft.
And this is all the more so given that, in modes of transport such as rail and maritime, States finance, depending on the circumstances, either partially or fully, security measures.
I therefore believe that we must remain firm vis-à-vis the council and defend amendment thirty-two of the report adopted by our transport committee to the very end.
I had another point to address briefly.

While I support the advances in non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe that the purpose of this directive is to establish a single, uniform European system of security levies.
While requiring adherence to common rules, it is necessary to allow Member States to retain their existing system of duty collection.
Thus, in states such as Spain, Italy, or France, royalties are voted on by Parliament and, in such cases, it must be the authority for appeals that serves as the independent supervisory body.
It is the purpose of amendment 40 that I hope you will be numerous in supporting when we vote on it.
Mr. President, Commissioner, the report I am submitting to Parliament attempts to explain that, in the fight against global warming, agriculture has a role and a place to play.
Nature reminds us this week that volcanoes, in particular, can have a significant impact on human activities and the climate.
But this still requires that men and Europe, in particular, take responsibility for combating what is known as global warming.
My report attempts to demonstrate that agriculture can simultaneously continue to decrease its carbon emissions, reduce its consumption of fossil fuels, and above all, in another
On the side, to actively participate in carbon sequestration to globally reduce carbon emissions and increase the amount of carbon fixed and sequestered.

This report attempts to demonstrate that in agriculture, we need to move away from an approach—how shall I put it?—that is compartmentalized, which consists of opening a directive each time a problem arises.

on the soils, on the water, on the pesticides, what else do I know, and to attempt to approach the agricultural question with the ambition of treating it in a comprehensive manner, in a systemic manner, and

Within this approach, we should be able to identify avenues for ensuring that agriculture, as I mentioned earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption but also actively participates in carbon sequestration.

It is particularly the role related to photosynthesis, to biomass, and then especially what is close to my heart, also linked to the soil, to this capacity that European soils have to sequester organic carbon.

I believe that this avenue I am opening in this report, and which I hope will be followed during the vote to be held in plenary session in Brussels, should enable European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability and to ensure

a transition to an agriculture that would place it ahead of a number of other continents or other agricultural systems, ensuring its ability to be economically viable, ecologically efficient, and I believe also, from that point forward, socially effective.

This report addresses a specific issue—the fight against global warming and agriculture—but it aspires, I hope, to open up other perspectives to inform, in particular, the debate that will take place on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
I address the Commission, I will address it, and I have done so frequently to the agricultural committees; I will also address the various ministers when I have the opportunity.
I believe we need to make a turn.
This 2013 pact must be ambitious.
She must rely on objectives that enable citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because Europe's agriculture must ensure both food security and commit to the path of sustainability.
That is, in any case, what I propose in this report, and that is what I hope the Parliament, by a large majority, will follow.

Mr. President, I would first like to emphasize that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments in closing their airspace in a targeted and temporary manner was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our citizens must take precedence over any other consideration, and under these circumstances, the attitude of certain airlines who are demanding the total and immediate reopening of airspace on the basis of one or two test flights appears, to say the least, indecent.

I believe it was Mr. Heéain earlier who spoke of the complementarity of modes of transport, particularly with the train, and I will seize the opportunity to say how much I regret that the aerial paralysis
has been exacerbated in certain countries, such as France, by the disorganization of rail transport due to strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
Returning to our subject, I wish to commend the Commission's decision to authorize the provision of public aid to airlines affected by current disruptions.
It is a common-sense decision in a context already marked by crisis, but its assistance must be of an exceptional nature.

In this regard, I wish that, among the criteria retained for their awarding, the exemplary nature demonstrated by companies in the compensation allocated to their clients who were victims of flight cancellations be included.
Indeed, it is not acceptable for certain companies to abuse the force majeure clause in order to evade their obligation to compensate passengers as stipulated in regulation 261/2004.
Travelers are victims of the current situation and, if no alternative solution is offered to them, they should not, furthermore, bear the financial cost.
Furthermore, travel agencies are relieved of the obligation to reimburse travelers for unused flights.
And this, too, is not normal.

Companies such as travel agencies have insurance policies that cover them in exceptional circumstances, such as the one we have been experiencing for a few days, and it is therefore essential to ensure that travelers are adequately compensated for canceled flights.
Mr. President, paddles, chaos, paralysis, cacophony, catastrophes, disasters—the monuments believe in the press to evoke the closure of European airspace and its consequences.
I will not dwell on what has already been said, particularly regarding the staggering, abyssal—one might be tempted to say—financial impact of this crisis, whether direct or indirect.

While I welcome the possibility of considering exceptional public aid for the aviation sector, already severely impacted since September 11, 2001, I remain perplexed by the European management of these events.

Considering that 750 European passengers have been affected, a significant number of whom remain stranded in various locations worldwide, and that economic losses are increasing exponentially with the passage of time, how can one explain that it took…?

It was not one, two, three, or four, but five days for the European transport ministers to meet via teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the creation of differentiated traffic zones.
Secondly, no one disputes the necessity of applying the precautionary principle as an absolute priority, but today, as traffic is progressively reauthorized in areas

Given the secured, unchanged meteorological conditions and the ongoing volcanic activity, one is entitled to question what additional safety assurances for passengers we could have provided more quickly.

Thirdly, an evolving action model has been developed—an evolution according to the meteorology—where the activity of the volcano can change in yield, and which will continue to proceed with the updated assessment of the safety of the corridors.
Should these test flights be conducted by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this situation persists, worsens, or recurs—which is likely—the management model implemented will need to incorporate greater coordination among Member States and special operational procedures based on real data, as well as improved

coordination of other modes of transport in exceptional circumstances, but let us also consider the necessary coordination of assistance with the repatriation of the tens of thousands of stranded passengers, who also have a right to information and assistance.
Or, until now, only isolated and national initiatives have been undertaken. Madame Delvo, who has the floor?

Thank you, Madame the President. I wanted, in turn, after other speakers, to express my gratitude to our colleague Mendes Di Vigo, who has accomplished remarkable work under sometimes passionate, and always fascinating, conditions.
Debates within the convention affairs committee were protracted; they lived up to the importance of the matter and the intensity of the interest obviously shown by
European parliamentary matters concerning them primarily and quite legitimately: the composition of our assembly and the modalities for designating its members.
Once again, the rapporteur has managed to gather opinions and contributions, sometimes differing, and to synthesize, I would say, these opinions and viewpoints into an extremely balanced text.
I wanted to thank him for it.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both concerning the calling of the CIG and concerning the transitional measures for the composition of our assembly, are characterized by realism, pragmatism, and effectiveness.
I know, I believe what, generally, citizens expect from Europe—on other subjects as well.

The President, Mr. Dali, Mr. the Commissioner,
it is with considerable force that this draft report, as presented just now by Mr. Péterlet, reprises the lines
Director of Communication for the European Commission and also draws inspiration from the European Parliament resolution of 10 April 2008 on the fight against cancer within our European Union.

Allow me to support the objectives of the European partnership envisioned by the European Commission to combat cancer more effectively, whether it concerns the importance of prevention and early detection, the development of a new model of cancer prevention, and above all, the reduction of inequalities within Member States.
I share the concerns and apprehensions expressed within the European Commission's communication and the draft report.
I wish to acknowledge the work carried out by Mr. Pterli, rapporteur, in the drafting of this report and the compromise proposals put forward to address the various amendments.

As rapporteur fictif for the Socialist and Democrats group, I have wished, among other things, to emphasize the following points: first, the increase in annual deaths related to cancers caused by exposure to carcinogenic agents in the workplace, but also the importance of improved access

information on medications for cancer patients, as well as the implementation of the REACH regulation and the regular updating of substances of very high concern, which lists carcinogenic substances, and support for initiatives aimed at preventing the import of goods.

containing chemical substances in origin and to strengthen the control of the presence of chemical substances within the European Union and, finally, the elaboration of guidelines for a common definition of disability that could include people suffering from chronic illnesses or cancer.
These are the questions we wished to raise while offering our support for this report project.
Madam President, the oil rig leak in the Bay of Mexico is a veritable ecological and economic catastrophe.
It appears that irregularities may have been noted in the United States Department of the Interior’s issuance of forest permits.
This would be a pardonable lightness, the consequences of which are incalculable and do not concern only the United States of America.

When we know that, worldwide, hundreds of offshore drilling authorizations are granted by states, if these authorizations are conceded with the same laxity, it would pose a serious problem for the entire world.
elected official from European ultraperipheral regions and Outermost Regions and Territories composed almost entirely, nearly 130
Distributed across the three continents, I must express here my very great concern regarding our islands in relation to offshore oil exploitation projects.
That is why it is imperative that the European Union, leading by example, rigorously reviews the safety and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms.
Furthermore, accidental or operational oil spills at sea, not necessarily attributable to Europe, are estimated at tens of thousands of tonnes annually.

Would it not be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives to ensure that offshore platforms now fall under the jurisdiction of an internationally recognized scientific authority, established in the form of an international agency?

Following Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancun, the European Union would be honored to initiate genuine global governance for the research, protection, and exploitation of the resources of the seabed.

The continuity of the Barcelona Process, the Union for the Mediterranean, represents an opportunity for the development of our relations with the countries of the eastern and southern Mediterranean basin.
And as the excellent report by Vincent Payillon highlights, we cannot neglect either the potential of this region nor the perils it embodies.

Yet, possessing the lucidity to recognize it, since the bombardment of Gaza and with the continuation of the colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean finds itself at an impasse.
The political aspect is stalled.
One is not even certain that the summit planned for next June in Barcelona will indeed take place.
I would not be surprised if, in the coming hours or days, we learn that he is on a day-synedetic basis.
We must not, however, abandon hope, but the European Union must take on greater responsibility in seeking a political solution.
We cannot leave to the United States the monopoly on the political management of this region’s crisis—a region that is ours—merely contributing to its development.
The development and stability of the Mediterranean are essential to our security and growth, and for this reason, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best instrument at our disposal.

Mr. President, Commissioner,
this concerns a matter of extreme importance regarding consumer protection.

A recent survey indicates that the situation regarding food security has deteriorated in the eyes of Europeans over the past ten years, and one in three consumers remains wary of the quality of products.
Updating, simplifying, and clarifying the labelling of food products within the European Union is an obligation for improved consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
Regarding the color code, we are in favor of this color code provided that it is accompanied by a reference to the nutritional values expressed as a percentage.
And then I am opposed to mandatory nutritional labeling for wines and spirits.
We request the development of regulations specific to wines and spirits within the next three years, rather than the five years proposed by the European Commission.
That is what I wished to indicate, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner.
Mr. President, Madam High Representative, this attack on a civilian vessel by Israeli commandos clearly demands an impartial and credible inquiry.
But what credence could we give to a commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack occurred in international waters; it therefore concerns the international community, and particularly interests Europe bordering the Mediterranean.
Europe, which should make itself heard more and become more deeply involved in the search for a political solution based on two states, each having Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making substantial financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but unfortunately, it is too absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of this Palestinian state.
The financial and budgetary good will that we demonstrate is not sufficient.
We must also express political will and take steps to ensure we are heard.
brutal raid on the Mavi Marmara by the Israeli army sparks emotions and condemnation
Emotion in the face of the nine victims of the civilian assault, condemnation because this reasoning in international waters constitutes a violation of international law.
In doing so, the Israeli government penalizes its people, for ultimately, we see, with the strengthening of extremism, the ultimate goal of security in the region receding further.
Yes, more than ever, the government of Israel must renounce the policy of force.
However, I wish to note that the extensive media coverage surrounding the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation appears indispensable to shed light on the assault, but also on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
I wish that the government of Israel would accept that this inquiry includes substantial international participation in order finally to find its way back to justice in this region.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I commend the new momentum spurred by the launch of the Partnership for Modernisation and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, if nothing else, would at least have the merit of highlighting how essential Russia is as a geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also welcome positive statements regarding cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
Some observations, however.

As the requirements of the Union are consistently highlighted, the interests or positions of its partner appear systematically underestimated or dismissed, whether in the field of energy or in how it can analyze the Eastern Partnership and the Atlanticist aspirations of its closest neighbors.

I also observe that the firmness demonstrated by most Member States and the Union in their discourse, the virulence of the condemnations of human rights violations, appears reserved solely for Russia.

The discourse is more focused on law enforcement, the diplomacy more restrained, as if we were dealing with China, for example, and its systematic violations of the rule of law. Not to mention the Laogai camps, this global factory in relation to minimal European social requirements when our French or European workers are unemployed?

Let me remind you of the adage from Agusta, father Augusta, towards the summits by narrow paths, for it is thus that I view the efforts of today's Russia, cleansed of the criminal Marxist poison that, for so many decades, has bled and imprisoned this country.
The current Russian Federation has demonstrated its ability to raise the head of an entire nation, despite the significant difficulties and disappointments it still has to overcome.

Then a little modesty, gentlemen Europhiles, particularly when the European super-state fails to achieve any of its lofty objectives despite increasingly costly means and the progressive domination of the states of Western and Central and Eastern Europe.
I cannot help but recall that this assembly showed, with regard to the Soviet Union—more communist—more leniency than it did for Russia.

They are, moreover, often the very same individuals who, yesterday, championed the unilateral disarmament of the West and participation in M. Gorbachov’s common house, and who today experience the most virtuous indignations and the greatest modesty regarding the Russia-EU partnership.

On this matter, I must inform you, if you are not already aware, of new historical phases that will emerge as a result of the progressive translation of Soviet secret archives, archives that a certain Mr. Pavel Sttroïlov has managed to acquire and which have already yielded and will continue to yield much.

Unpleasant surprises regarding the classic dogma concerning the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was in fact Gorbatov himself, and the blunder of today’s Eurocentric powers who then, with enthusiasm, wished to make certain Soviet projects possible.
At the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for European states, and our relations must be strengthened to the benefit of all parties.

This country is far closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interests, or common risks than are certain states that you are nevertheless preparing to admit to the European Union.
President of the Council, it is often said that necessity makes law.
Faced with the crisis, an undeniable truth that expresses a necessity having become unavoidable: that of innovating, of being creative.

In this capacity, I welcome the step taken by the Council—a step that, I hope will ultimately be a giant leap—leading us toward genuine economic governance, for let us not deceive ourselves, the mere coordination of economic policies will remain insufficient.
May we arrive at a genuine budgetary federation, not forced by circumstances, but because we ourselves would have decided upon it.
Let us return to the Council’s decision, which nevertheless pleases me.
Strengthening the preventative pillar of the Stability and Growth Pact is an excellent thing, but there is no genuine fiscal discipline without sanctions for those who deviate from it.
They have been strengthened, but not yet specified, which is a regret.

Otherwise, I will express my satisfaction, among other things, with the decisions made, such as the well-known competitiveness assessment dashboard, because it is fundamentally about reconnecting with competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
Greetings once again regarding the project to establish a bank tax, the acceptance of a taxation of financial transactions, and the acceleration of the reform of financial regulations.
Mr. President of the Council, just a few months ago, or even a few weeks, these decisions and orientations appeared unrealistic, illusory, or even genuinely hypothetical.
You are correct; it is true—it represents a profound cultural shift at the scale of European microstate policy.
That being said, it is now imperative that, in October, the states implement these guidelines very concretely.

It will now depend on the Council whether the step taken is a historic giant leap or merely a pious wish, something we will all bitterly regret and, in particular, the majority of citizens will have to endure on a daily basis.

Mr. President, we have, in fact, already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents. Many groups are divided on this fast-track report, and evidently, Parliament, all groups still need to discuss because there are problems, contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
That is why we requested postponing the debate and vote on the Gallop report, that is to say, to September 2, when the conference of presidents will take place.
Therefore, it is a very straightforward matter.
Given that the fruit is not ripe, let us allow it the summer to ripen and discuss the matter in September.
Madam President, I confess to struggling to follow my colleagues who so enjoy flexing their muscles and claiming a monopoly on our legitimacy in relation to the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often laughable.
But, when the members of this household, through diligence and conviction, assert a reasoned position when
We advocate for what appears to be a shared European interest against rigid states, the situation shifting entirely around it.
In this debate concerning European oversight, the Parliament played that role.
Regarding the European Systemic Risk Board, of which I am the fictitious rapporteur for my group, I have defended, as has the rapporteur, Ms. Goulard, an ambitious line.
I have established mechanisms ensuring a degree of effectiveness and I have emphasized the supreme importance of the European Central Bank.
Why?
Because the European Central Bank is indeed the only Community institution within this framework and because it has demonstrated its seriousness.
Out of Christian charity, I shall refrain from mentioning the names of all the institutions and all those prominent figures who abruptly vanished during the storm.
We can consider ourselves fortunate to have had at least one captain on board during the height of the crisis.
I would therefore be reassured to see tomorrow macroprudential oversight supported by a strong Community institution, while microprudential oversight will inevitably remain fragmented.
In certain troubled situations, the European Systemic Risk Board must begin its work as quickly as possible.
The future will show whether adjustments will be necessary, but it is essential to begin on sound foundations, as systemic risks affect the entire banking sector, European and global.
Mr. President, the final agreement reached on the overhaul of the Industrial Emissions Directive is more than acceptable, and I commend the work of compromise that has been achieved.

This final package recapitulates the key amendment points that I, along with several of my colleagues on the environment committee, advocated for, with the aim of ensuring this text became ambitious yet realistic legislation.
Firstly, maintaining a degree of flexibility for businesses and relevant authorities regarding the granting of exemptions.
Next, I would like to acknowledge the new version of the OSN, which has been so controversial and, now limited to certain sectors, appears much more feasible.

It is also important to emphasize that the agreement reached allows for better coordination with the ETS Directive and definitively removes from the text of the new directive the irrelevant idea of creating a market for SO2 and NOx quotas.
Several caveats to bear in mind, however, and particularly those concerning land.
As Directive SOL remains pending, this significant issue will unfortunately be addressed only by Member States that possess their own legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement reached following the trilogue negotiations.

A tremendous amount of work has been undertaken on all sides to prevent this text from being referred to conciliation, a text which, I must reiterate, is of crucial importance both to industry and to European environmental policy.
Madam President, each day brings its share of information that shows the extent of the ecological disaster caused in the Gulf of Mexico with the rupture of the offshore platform.
But let us not forget that other disasters of this kind occur elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular of what is happening today and has been happening for a long time already, in Nigeria.
That is why, in addition to the moratorium, for new drilling, I believe there is a need to promote stricter rules regarding platform management, not only European rules, but also international rules.
As for the European Union, I believe it is necessary for it to proactively equip itself with measures to combat this disaster, and I think that is evident.
also that all of this argues, as Ms. Damanki has said, for a firm and resolute choice in favor of clean and renewable energies.
The European Union should lead by example in this regard.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur as the European Union prepares to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports 500,000 tonnes of beef.
A new opening of our market will occur to the benefit of breeders from disadvantaged European zones, without a guarantee of respect for health and social standards.
We cannot accept it.
Europe purchases thirty-eight million tonnes of soybeans and animal feed.
These substantial imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize over nineteen million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies: Cargill, ADM, and Bonsch.
Between 2001 and 2004, soybean cultivation destroyed over 1.2 million hectares of tropical and equatorial forests.
It was one of the primary causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the loss of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on regaining autonomy in plant-based proteins for livestock feed.
Environmentally responsible agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be nullified by this proposed bilateral agreement.
Once again, the European Commission is selling out its agriculture and farmers to obtain random concessions for service companies.
These concessions will serve no purpose for peasant families in Mercosur, but will benefit the interests of agroindustrial groups.
To be convinced, it is sufficient to read the report from the Tyson group, an American company and a heavyweight player in the international meat market.
who announces having invested in Brazil, and I quote, and this is in his report, using that country as a platform for exporting to Europe.
Other companies, such as Doux, had already anticipated this move by acquiring the Franco-Brazilian group Soulul in 1988.
Numerous poultry farmers, particularly in Brittany, had been affected by this operation.
Europe, without wishing to pursue its policy of relocation by amplifying its attacks.
against the peasants. we must stop
Mr. President, numerous colleagues are concerned about the consequences for European agriculture that the reopening of negotiations for an association agreement with Mercosur could have.
My group and I share these concerns.

It is, indeed, something to be feared, and as a Member of Parliament representing an outermost region, I have experience with the banana accords. It is therefore to be feared that an agreement with Mercosur may impose a cost on many European agricultural sectors.
That is precisely why an impact study is absolutely necessary.
It is also to be feared that this agreement may further shift Mercosur’s agriculture somewhat too strongly towards a productivist model, to the detriment of small farms that exist in these countries.
A balance must be found so that this agreement does not transform Latin American and European continents into superpowers essentially anchored in the dogma of mercantilism. Mr. President, thank you.
Mr. President, I would simply like to say that perhaps we haven't structured our agenda very well today.

If we allow free trade agreements to enter the territory of Europe, bringing products that do not respect either our social standards or our environmental standards, the reform of the CAP will be for naught.
Very clearly, we cannot remain in a state of hypocrisy or, on one hand, impose environmental, health traceability, and safety constraints.
To our farmers, on the one hand, because it is necessary to protect consumers and, on the other, to allow products to enter our continent freely without respecting [any standards].
The question underlying the negotiation with Mercosur is precisely that one.

The manner in which events were initiated, notwithstanding what we are told about the Parliament being very well informed that matters transpired with the utmost transparency and clarity, does not lead us to form a positive assessment of a negotiation that unfolds while, in parallel, negotiations continue at the WTO.
In the name of consumer protection coherence and the protection of our farmers, I do not believe that we should continue down this path.

Madam President, I would also like to acknowledge the work done by the rapporteur, José Boveis, to commend the Commissioner, and then the intervention of Mr. Deès, who preceded me in discussing the objectives of this report.

I believe it is very important that we keep in mind that in the debate we are having, we need to address a problem related to price volatility in agriculture and especially to the fact that when prices
They increase rapidly at the distribution level, but when prices decrease at the production level, there is no impact on consumers.
There is indeed a problem with the organization of the sector, and there is indeed a problem with the distribution of what is known as added value within the sector.

I believe that José Boveis’ report offers perspectives on several points that should be highlighted, and this is something I am genuinely addressing to the Commission in an effort to break free from this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first, of course, is the organization of the sector and the power dynamic within it. Therefore
What proposals do we make to ensure producers collectively gather and organize to have greater influence within the sector for negotiation purposes?
That is the question you raised, Commissioner, regarding inter-professional collaborations, but it is also a question posed on the basis of the contractual framework that will be implemented.
I argue here in the report that this contractual basis constitutes a European framework.
One cannot allow each country to resolve this issue.
There must be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
It is a proposal, an inseparable avenue for me.
I am, of course, referring to the issue of price transparency.
On that point, I am in favor of establishing this observatory, which is absolutely necessary so that we can inform consumers about price fluctuations.
Voilà, I support the propositions that are being made, and I hope, as Mr. Des said, that there will be a majority to pursue [this].
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I wished today to commend this debate, which once again underscores the Union’s need to acknowledge and value its regional diversity.
At this time of negotiation for the new framework programmes 2014, it seemed to me less necessary to emphasize the accommodations that specific regions must benefit from.
Issues of territorial continuity and cohesion must be at the center of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous, island, or sparsely populated territories requires more than a collection of exceptional measures.
We need a horizontal approach.
We must establish the instruments capable of fostering a synergistic coexistence of all areas of community action in order to strengthen their added value.
Furthermore, as representative of the outermost regions, I await, and patiently so, the Union’s new strategy for the OCTs that the Commission’s services have promised us for early 2011.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first, I concur with my colleague's position regarding the Council’s absence from this Parliamentary meeting.
I find that somewhat careless on the part of the Council, and I want to state that as well.
As the next summit on October 6th approaches, China and the European Union must unequivocally and resolutely seek to advance together on the issue of climate change.
Last year, at this same time, we were already engaged in this very chamber, urging Europe to do everything possible to achieve an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We observed that the result did not meet our expectations and aspirations.
So, the concerns a year later are the same, if anything even more pronounced.

To enable us today to constrain or convince our partners, we must demonstrate that our resolve is absolutely intact, showing, for instance, that we provide the means to honor our commitments to Southern countries.
To that end, the establishment of innovative funding mechanisms and I heard yesterday President Sarkozy’s speech at the UN becomes a necessary certainty.
For instance, the implementation of a carbon tax at our borders is not to be ruled out.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that are not going far enough with their climate commitments, far more than a threat ultimately, and a means of protecting our jobs and businesses, especially to better address the pre-crisis situation.

Madam President, I do not support the need to revalue family leave. Raising the minimum threshold for maternity leave is a positive development, a benefit, and we should not be entirely populist in comparing the economic impact to the qualitative benefits, which are difficult to quantify.

But the problem is essentially of two kinds: firstly, the economic context, which is true, but not sufficient to leave millions of families stranded for decades. Secondly, the legal shortcomings of the report, as the text includes several types of family leave whose legal foundations are irreconcilable.
Let us consider the adoption leave stipulated in the text, on par with maternity and paternity leave.
I personally appreciate, as an adoptive mother and for all those I represent, the desire to grant equivalent rights to those of biological mayors.
I am, in fact, the small addendum that Mrs. Morin added to the EtréLA report.

If the objective is to strengthen women's health and rights and women's access to the labor market, adoptive mothers, who become mothers in the same way as others, are entitled to the same rights and the same workplace protections.
These are mothers like any others, except that they adopt a child of plus or minus twelve months, and, incidentally, there is no discrimination, please, as it is stated in the text.
Regarding adoption, therefore, I regret that the text has been so little explored.
It wasn't even informed by the Rambo impact study.
All of this is not well developed, which is clearly a point of weakness.

Nevertheless, despite these caveats, I will support Ms. Estrella’s report because, beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better assume their parental responsibilities in a society of

Increasingly disillusioned with the education of these young people, but furthermore, because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their work or sacrificing their work for their children.
Finally, we do not sit on the Council but on the Parliament. If we, directly elected representatives, are not ambitious, tell me who will be.
Madam President, Commissioner, President of the Council, I would like to speak and revisit the debate as it has unfolded thus far.
We discussed a 2011 budget with the constraints we know, namely those of a profound crisis affecting Europe, with national public deficits, which can lead to two hypotheses.
These national public deficits constrain the European deficit, or these deficits at the national level must give a new direction and renewed impetus at the European scale.
That is where the question lies.
I ask you, Mr. Commissioner, above all to try to think when discussing a budgetary revision, when we begin to speak of budgetary perspectives for post-2013, to not
to remain wholly immersed in the context of the crisis, except to tell and to tell all the citizens of Europe that, indeed, Europe will remain in crisis for a long time.
Our entire challenge lies in managing the crisis and reducing our deficits and debt, but also in preparing for the crisis's exit.
And it is there that the budgetary question arises.

We will not be able to emerge from the crisis, and Joseph Dale stated this immediately, unless the European budget, because it is European, is capable of providing us with the means to regain what we currently lack in terms of growth, job creation, innovation, and research.

This is the crux of the matter, and it is on these grounds that we must discuss the budget, rather than constantly incorporating the question of the crisis, the question of deficits, as we too often do. And on this point, the Council is excellent.

I noted that in Deauville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even announced a treaty reform in advance, without even having discussed anything at all with Mr. Van Rompuy, to sanction all the states that would not respect budgetary discipline tomorrow.

Here's where we stand today at the Council, while Parliament requests one thing, and in particular from the Commission, which is to try and advance the European project—and that is happening through the budget.
So you have noted a number of things with which we are entirely in agreement.
There is a need for greater fixity.
Clearly, we must find a way together to develop a much more flexible budget, because these are necessities and the responsiveness of Europe is at stake.
This also, of course, involves setting priorities and ensuring budgetary efficiency for the European Union.
We will all agree on this, all agree—it is a necessity.
But where we need to be clear with each other is that we need a timeline, we need to jointly set objectives, Commissioner. It cannot remain just words, just commitments, just…

These texts are, incidentally, very interesting and I share them almost entirely. But now, it will be necessary to get down to specifics, and in particular concerning a crucial question around which we are revolving: own resources.
How do we ensure that we have our own resources tomorrow for Europe, not for Europe itself, but for all European citizens, and rediscover together a path to growth that is even stronger for Europe?
It is your turn, Sir.
Mr. President, I would like to focus my remarks on the preparation for the upcoming G20 summits.

Everything has been said by previous speakers regarding European economic governance, on the necessity of strengthening European economic governance, of reinforcing the Stability and Growth Pact, and of better associating the European Parliament and, of course, national parliaments with the process.
I would like to briefly cite two challenges facing our nations and facing G20 members, which must be addressed within the framework, in my opinion, of the forthcoming G20 meetings.
The challenge of currency wars is that of commodity price volatility.
I believe that, on these two subjects which are veritable threats to global growth and which cause very significant imbalances on our planet, the Union

European [policy] is managing to organize itself, to establish common positions, and to provide itself with the means to speak with a single voice at upcoming G20 summits, Seoul, but also those that will follow, and more broadly, on the world stage. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate our colleague Diogo Feyo on the quality of the report and the ambitious proposals it contains.
This also demonstrates that the European Parliament is taking its full place in a debate that is decisive for the future of Europe, and we can only welcome this.
Moreover, the Greek crisis served as a revealing indicator of the dysfunctions undermining the economic governance of the European Union.
I take note of Mr. Feio's proposal regarding the establishment of a permanent mechanism for financial stability.
We must also address the problem at its root.
For this, I believe the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact and, in particular, the sanctions.
It is indispensable if we want a sustainable resolution of the states’ budgetary situation, which is not always popular.
It is restrictive, but we have no choice.

Mr. President, I believe the report clearly demonstrates the stakes involved in the marine environment in terms of fishing, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological resources, combined with climate change.
It represents a considerable potential for development that must be secured, protected, and sustainably enhanced, as the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also notes, rightly so, that the European Union is the world’s leading maritime power and that these outermost regions offer it the largest exclusive economic zone globally.
Given such an observation, it therefore falls to the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a major maritime policy.
If it is not the world’s foremost maritime power doing so, who else will?
But it must be noted that the resolution does not go very far down this path.
It is not with 50 million euros that one can claim to occupy a leadership position in global politics.
Finally, while the outermost regions have a recognized strategic position, being present in all oceans, it would have
It would have been judicious to have them play a major role in a grand ocean strategy, which, unfortunately, the report did not retain, and I regret this. Thank you, Mr. President.
Madame, Monsieur le Commissaire, I would like to revisit the anti-counterfeiting agreement currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement raises questions in the United States as well, particularly among officials at the United States Patent and Trademark Office.
Furthermore, seventy-five American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
He rules that ACTA, this simple executive agreement, would be contrary to the American Constitution.
as the European Parliament prepares, as you know, to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, which continues to raise significant concerns and is far from achieving unanimous support
Among our citizens, I believe it would be useful to have from our American counterparts a very clear response. On two points, can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
Is ACTA, in their view, a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement already lacking the participation of China, India, and Brazil, and which would not be implemented by the United States, loses much of its credibility.
I thank you.

Mr. President, throughout this difficult birthing process of the directive on alternative investment funds, I have consistently advocated for the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether or not they are based in the European Union.
This principle sounds like an obviousness, but its lack of obviousness has encountered countless difficulties.
The result presented to us today is of a satisfactory nature.
I thank the negotiators and especially our rapporteur, Mr. Gasès, who, after this particularly painful labor, deserves a substantial maternity leave.
I would particularly like to emphasize that the question of the treatment of third countries must nevertheless be observed in two ways, whether one is inside or outside the European Union.
Thanks notably to the European Parliament, all funds sold within the European Union will effectively be subject to comparable regulation.
One can therefore speak of Love’s playing field, to a greater or lesser extent.

It remains the case, however, that during the transitional period, non-EU entities will benefit from the national placement regime, whereas funds and managers of the European Union will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter.

The situation differs in markets located outside the European Union. There, European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for funds from third countries.
It would therefore be much more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world, as they will be less flexible and more culturally specific.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was, to some extent, inevitable.

Regarding custodians, knowing as well that we will make the practice more restrictive, particularly due to the new responsibilities incumbent upon them, the increased costs should lead to substantial changes in the profession.

Mr. President, I am not saying this to demonstrate my opposition, but to indicate that this new regulation is far from trivial; its implementation, which is necessary, will also entail difficulties of which we must be aware.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, particularly at the beginning of the 21st century, patients need appropriate information in order to be fully involved in their care pathway, knowing where to seek care, deciding on the best treatment in agreement with healthcare professionals, and adhering strictly to the prescribed treatment.
Today, patients demand independent, comparative information tailored to individual needs.
Unfortunately, the proposals for revising the directive transmitted by the European Commission did not adequately address the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical firms, which appears to us as nonsensical in terms of responding to patients' actual needs.
This operation offers no benefit either to citizens or to Member States.
It signified, conversely, additional bureaucracy, an increase in expenses, and putting patients at risk.
It is for these reasons that we initially presented a draft version of these texts, thereby requesting that the Commission review its own.

This approach, also adopted by my colleague Carl Schulter of the Green Group, has enabled our rapporteur, Mr. Fechner, whom I salute, to undertake a significant revision of the Commission’s proposals.

Concurrently, we had submitted approximately sixty amendments aimed at further protecting the health of our citizens and facilitating patients’ access to independent, comparative, and personalized information.

The adoption of these amendments in the environmental affairs committee has enabled greater emphasis to be placed on patients' rights to information, rather than making the provision of information an option for pharmaceutical industries.

In light of the compromise amendments obtained, we have decided to withdraw our position of rejection of the texts, and the substance of the text having evolved in a positive direction over the past few months.
The draft report, as amended, has managed to offset the European Commission’s initial proposals.

However, we will continue to refuse that healthcare professionals be used as instruments to distribute their patients, brochures, and information provided by pharmaceutical firms without any oversight from health authorities.
Similarly, we will oppose the authorization of industrial campaigns, of information, particularly regarding vaccination.
Information cannot flow freely from pharmaceutical firms.

Experience demonstrates that we must be very vigilant, and indeed, I conclude that what happened with the Mediator medication shows how vigilant we must be and ensure that this point of equilibrium, as we have sought it with this draft report,

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Madam Minister, unity and realism will be discussed—at least, that is my hope—during tomorrow’s vote on our resolution concerning this 16th Conference of the Parties on climate change.

I hope in this way that our designated commissioner will be able to champion the pragmatic objectives we will need to achieve collectively, but also to uphold the indispensable conditions set forth by Europe which are associated with it.
In these negotiations, we must also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of fairness held by our citizens and our industries.
It is the world that must combat climate change, and not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of an insufficiently protected intellectual property will be essential.

Green technologies must benefit the greatest number of people, but we must not, for that reason, devalue our present and future knowledge, nor those very individuals engaged in this essential fight against climate change.

Similarly, requesting common methodologies for calculating emissions, along with verification and publication of data so that all industries and stakeholders are subject to the same standards, appears to be a perfectly legitimate request, and not a negotiating tactic.
Finally, more controversially—as my colleague raised earlier—the shortcomings of the current system of clean development mechanisms will also need to be addressed.
Dear colleagues, we are all too well aware, with regret, that the true negotiating power is not held by the European Parliament.

But the desire of many Members of the European Parliament, including myself, to work and contribute to a positive outcome of this conference must be encouraged, and not overlooked, as we have perhaps felt these past few days.
If Europe wishes to be strong within international dialogues, it must be so for all these legislators.
Madame President, the European Union frequently presents economic partnership agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
Does she also despair of not seeing these agreements signed as quickly as possible?
But the question that concerns us is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that would be beneficial to them.
Clearly, assessments diverge regarding the quality of these agreements, and as long as these differences in assessment persist, ACP countries will hesitate to sign them.
Would it not be appropriate to extend the dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of the ACP countries?
They wish to discuss development strategies, while Europe often responds with merely market opening.
It is this listening that is required by the ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly.
I believe that other European bodies should proceed in the same manner if we are to build a genuine strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Mr. President, Christians are undoubtedly among the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, legitimate targets, and the objective is their simple and complete departure from this region, a region that saw the birth of Christianity and in which their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events at the Baghdad cathedral are only the culmination of a situation we have passively observed for far too long.
The European Union, as a global actor and trading partner of many countries in this region, has a responsibility to express its strong indignation in view of the situation.
Discriminations, whatever their form, cannot be tolerated.
Democracy will not be victorious in this region until the most fundamental human rights, such as freedom of religion, are respected.
Colleagues, we are all concerned by the serious crisis currently underway in Côte d'Ivoire.

It is evident that the constitutional council of this country’s decision to challenge, in violation of the electoral code, the election results officially proclaimed by the Independent Electoral Commission is unanimously condemned by the international community.
The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the European Union-ACP Parliamentary Joint Assembly, KoAS, and soon, certainly, the European Parliament demand respect for the official declaration of…

results of the elections and the installation of the new President of the Republic, as recognized by the Independent Electoral Commission. The Independent Electoral Commission, which, I recall, is an entity validated by the UN.
All political groups in the European Parliament have expressed, in a joint statement, their agreement on these essential points.

They also called for averting any escalation of tension in the country that could lead to civil war, which would be a human, social, and economic disaster for Côte d'Ivoire—something that must be avoided at all costs.

Madam President, I also wanted to thank our four rapporteurs, who have carried out remarkable work and have brought significant added value from the European Parliament to the text initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizen initiative that we, at the PPE, are preparing to vote with enthusiasm is a major advancement of the Lisbon Treaty.
Let us not be deceived. This instrument can genuinely alter the European political landscape, provided it is used with both responsibility and boldness. I repeat, responsibility and boldness.
It can contribute to bringing European citizens directly into the European political debate.
It can contribute to the emergence of a European public opinion, that is to say, European citizens who debate together, take positions together, and unite on genuinely European issues.
But let us not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our Member States to swiftly adopt the necessary implementing measures where required. Let us not disappoint our citizens; it concerns the strengthening of European democracy.
Mr. President, I too, like several of our colleagues, wished to address the issue of the persecution of Christians worldwide, particularly Christians in the East.
It is unnecessary to recall the horrific acts recently committed.
I would like to reiterate, nonetheless, that defending Christians in the Orient, as everywhere in the world, advocating for religious freedom, the diversity of
Belief is advocating for freedom, democracy, and human rights, values at the heart of the European project and which are, of course, we are all convinced here, universal values.
It is truly time now, beyond indignation, emotion, and solemn condemnations, of course, it is truly time now to move from words to actions.
I urgently call upon the authorities of the European Union, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, but also all our leaders, the Ministers of Foreign Affairs.
Implement precise measures to establish a clear, concrete action plan to make respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Madam the High Representative, we all agree that the situation in the Sahel region has deteriorated considerably.
And allowing a lawless zone to establish itself within a European port is a danger that we must firmly and without delay combat.
Extremist groups are proliferating and threatening the lives of civilian populations.
It is now my turn to lament the loss of human life and the hostage-taking, and to express concern for European nationals present there.
Until now, Morocco has been a bulwark against all kinds of trafficking originating from the Sahel.
Now, drug, arms, and human traffickers are circumventing Morocco by passing through Mauritania to the Canary Islands and then to the European Union.
It seems to me that it is the responsibility of the European Union to act to help these states bring an end to these threats.
The security of Europe is at stake on our territory, but also in its immediate vicinity.
It is time for us to act, and I urge the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to help restore security in the Sahel.
It was said, but I join the expressions of sympathy and support that have already been voiced towards the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
It represents a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedom.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to state that the European Union, which, it has been said, has distinguished itself by its lack of reaction, must indeed stand alongside the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples to help them successfully implement their countries’ opening to reforms and establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support Tunisian leaders in undertaking a peaceful transition, to prepare for the organization of upcoming elections to secure freedom, and to enable the Tunisian people to find prosperity, development, and social peace, an economy that will allow young people to find employment.

I would conclude by saying that the Union for the Mediterranean faces a significant challenge because the Jasmine Revolution triggered a wave across all the states of the Maghreb, the Near East, and the Middle East.
She must implement a robust strategy towards these countries.
However, in the face of this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of peoples, and stability.
Sir Commissioner, my colleagues have repeatedly reminded you.

At a time when Europe is questioning a common strategy for its supply of raw materials, and particularly rare earth elements, we cannot neglect the immense potential represented by the intelligent valorization of our waste.

Strengthening European standards to improve the functioning of collection channels, address issues of leakage or illegal export, or even increase our collection targets, but also must form the core of this legislation.
Let us not forget the principal actor in the success or failure of this regulation: the consumer.
Citizen empowerment is crucial if we wish to implement effective legislation,
And to that end, my dear Carolines, ecocontribution, among other systems, has proven to be a most pertinent tool.

Producers of electrical and electronic equipment must, of course, become more involved in the collection and recycling system, but citizens cannot be absolved of responsibility for the waste they generate.
Our citizens must be actors, not spectators, in European environmental policy.
Madam President, Mr. President, Commissioner, I would first like to echo Ms. McGuinness’s observation regarding the essential link between food and agriculture.
The subject that concerns us is the fluctuation of food prices and the consequences this can have for a number of populations worldwide, but also in Europe.
I would first like to attempt to share an observation.

The trend of rising agricultural prices and agricultural raw materials is, in my view, a long-term trend that will persist for three essential reasons: the world’s demographic evolution and the increase

the global population. A second element is that we have entered, with climate change, a period of climatic hazards that pose a problem, whether it be drought or whether it be flooding. The third point, because the world is also developing.
With new emerging countries, consumption levels are increasing.
The tension on agricultural markets and agricultural commodities is a significant trend.
It is exacerbated by price volatility, and price volatility is a consequence of the financialization of the global economy.
It is on this subject that we must also address it, if we want to resolve both the agricultural and the food question.

To this end, what the Commissioner stated is important. There are two elements: yes, transparency regarding inventories is needed, but a public policy on inventories is also required, both in Europe and a management of inventories on a global scale, particularly at the level of the UN.

Secondly, there must be regulation of financial markets and financial speculation, particularly by refusing to allow speculative volume to become disconnected from the physical quantities exchanged on the markets.

We cannot accept that, on the matter of food, speculators should speculate without considering the consequences this may have, since we are talking about the world's food and humanity. I conclude by saying
This leads me to two major consequences: we need a strong European policy, and we strategically reaffirm Europe’s commitment to being a global food and agricultural actor.
Secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that, globally and with Europe as an actor, we reinvest in agriculture, as we will need all forms of agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Commissioner, as in 2008, how are agricultural commodity prices advancing on global markets?
We are only at three percent of the 2008 level.
the decline in production in certain traditional exporting regions due to climate change, the diversion of cereals for biofuel production, and speculation
Financial factors that exacerbate upward trends are responsible for this situation, as demonstrated by reports from the IMF, French authorities, and also stated by the Commission.
The consequences of this new food crisis are hitting hard the 1.2 billion inhabitants worldwide living below 1 dollar and
Since October, an additional forty-four million people have joined those living below the poverty line.
Two days before the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take similar measures to those passed in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the U.S. administration has required the limitation and transparency of positions taken by financial entities in agricultural commodities markets.
This advancement is a first step to counter the appetites of speculators.
The impact is dramatic for European livestock farmers as well.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are failing.
Five years ago, wheat was worth 100 euros per tonne. Today, it is trading at nearly 300 euros.
The situation has therefore changed completely.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals. It would be well advised today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot, in 32,014, find solutions.
We must confront the crisis, and I propose three concrete actions.
Firstly, the creation of stockpiles in cereal-producing countries to make them available to livestock farmers at subsidized prices immediately.
Secondly, the indexing of meat prices paid to breeders on the evolution of livestock feed costs.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism for transferring a portion of the subsidies intended to support cereals to animal production. Thank you.
Mr. President, are we in Europe prepared to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there's a caveat.
The H1N1 influenza episode of 2009-2010 demonstrated that each Member State reacted independently, with little coherence or even solidarity.

As a fictitious rapporteur on this matter, I believe these observations needed to be made, but more importantly, we should have gone further, offering constructive and concrete proposals for our citizens. It must be said, and this is what I find most regrettable, that we have likely lost some of their trust in public health messages.

The report by Ms. Rivasi, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes into consideration her fundamental priorities, which include, among others, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between Member States, improved coordination with the
European health agencies, a clarification of the roles of European structures for health risk management, an evaluation of vaccination strategies and communication implemented in Member States.
It is therefore a good report. I congratulate the rapporteur. It remains, of course, to be seen whether it will remain so.
It is the responsibility of our Member States, who retain the essential competencies in this area. It is therefore a genuine responsibility to assume towards our citizens.
Mr. President, it is now my turn to express my profound emotion following the cowardly assassination last March of the Pakistani Minister responsible for Christian minority affairs, Mr. Batâti.
This act of terrorist violence follows numerous other assassinations of courageous, tolerant Pakistanis, lovers of human rights, human rights defenders, and women’s rights advocates, I must say.

Once again, we urge the Pakistani government to shed full light on this cowardly assassination and to effectively, truly effectively, ensure the protection of individuals threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
I think, of course, initially, but not exclusively, of Mme Chery Raymond.
I also wanted, once again, with force, to request all competent institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations aimed at
to prepare future cooperation agreements, notably the cooperation agreement between the Union and Pakistan, including a clause on respect for freedom of religion and respect for human rights.
Mr. President, for your records, with the crisis and the explosion of the real estate and credit bubble, the Irish State had to intervene to support the banks.
The Irish public deficit—the cumulative budget balance of central, local, and, in particular, social security administrations—is estimated at thirty-two percent of gross domestic product in 2010.

If the Irish government, which can scarcely refinance itself on the markets, wishes to access loans from the mechanism and the European Stability Financial Fund, it will have to meet obligations of a social and fiscal nature, even though these areas fall under the principle of subsidiarity.
In our view, this is not contradictory.
As a physician, I would say that in cases of fever, it is pointless to prescribe antipyretics blindly without seeking to treat the underlying cause.
Should these funds be allocated, it falls to that State to undertake a financial cleanup in order to address its excessive deficit and rectify past errors.
This austerity plan is projected to increase GDP by ten percent over the next four years.

Just as an individual bank, without interfering in their personal life and management, will condition a personal loan on proof of solvency, so too can the European Union lend to Ireland based on consolidated solvency.
without interfering in its private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

It is in this way that, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity, the European Union, based on a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvency is achieved through a reduction of the statutory minimum wage and an adjustment of pensions, without exempting itself from fiscal measures.
It is up to Ireland to choose whether or not to implement these measures.

It is not an opening for European Union interference in areas of subsidiarity, which would allow, for example, the dangerously imposing of a European minimum wage, but a protection of the stability of the euro zone through a process of mutual guarantee.

It is, of course, appropriate to assist Ireland, as with other countries in difficulty, which also protects us, but not at any price, particularly that of witnessing a state incapable of repaying its debts in the long term, thereby weakening its citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April—as many of us have said just now—provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and ineffectiveness of European airspace.
Each of us, in this chamber, has been directly affected.
Five million of our fellow citizens found themselves stranded, lacking viable alternative transportation options.
And a year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still awaited.

A first crisis management exercise, as you stated, Commissioner, related to volcanic ash, is indeed scheduled for April 13 and 14, coordinated by eurocontrol of ICAO and dDIATA, but it is essential that ESA assume genuine leadership for the coordination of safety measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the waves from London and Toulouse must be refined using more modern technological means.

These data, as was observed last April, can nevertheless be contradictory and may lead each Member State to make decisions concerning the closure of their airspace less motivated by information than by emotion.
In this context, ESA’s role is essential for providing a harmonized interpretation of this data, as well as for ensuring the centralization and proper dissemination of information.
Beyond the reporting of VAC data, the AISAA must establish a mechanism for collecting available data by closely associating Member States, airlines, and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all stakeholders will prevent the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission to be able, with the ESA, to present concrete proposals rapidly that will fully integrate into the realization of the European single sky.
Dear colleagues, this tax is important.
It is not a revolution. We cannot say that everything was going badly before and that everything is perfect now.
However, it does present a number of major advances at this provisional stage of our work.

The main concerns, in my opinion, relate to better regulation of distance selling, and particularly online. This is addressed in chapter 3, as it is necessary to strengthen consumer rights in this area.
E-commerce is very useful; it expands the consumer's choice, allows them to obtain the lowest prices, and also enables small and medium-sized enterprises and artisans to find new markets.

To progress in this field, it was necessary to do so in a truly European manner, that is to say, on a few very specific points, to establish a complete harmonization of the rights and obligations of each.
Very concretely, it was necessary that an Italian customer purchasing from a Belgian or German website be aware that, from now on, they would benefit from the same rights, the same protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that their withdrawal period will extend to fourteen days throughout the Union.
This means that he pays the total amount immediately, without fear of an unpleasant surprise afterward.
That means that, thanks to a double-click, it will correctly validate its order.
Obviously, all of this will disrupt certain habits.
In many details, there are subtleties in national law of which each is convinced are fundamental, whereas sometimes they are not even found in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to modify one’s habits somewhat in the service of the common and general interest.
Let us be clear: this text will still need to be improved, and we will need to do so in the coming weeks with the Council and the Commission.
I have appreciated the openings that have just been made in this regard.
But we have already done substantial work, thanks to our rapporteur, André Ashchoab, whom I warmly thank.
But the true fruit of this work is above all the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all political groups.
Consumer confidence regarding the European Union’s internal market is extremely fragile.
This political unanimity was necessary to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
At item number seven following the first paragraph, a pull quote will ensure respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, particularly the
