The question that arises today stems from the 2011 management of the Schengen Area.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s; it is, on the contrary, a space that has continued to expand in recent years and which now comprises twenty-five states, three of whom are not members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, cooperation within the Schengen Area must therefore adapt to the reality it encompasses today, a reality that is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

It is in this sense that the proposals of the Italian and French governments, and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration, should be read.
Mutual trust between the States party to the Schengen Area is, of course, a cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air leaks, the entire system becomes defective.
It must therefore be possible for other States to respond to this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly regulated control over these borders.
In doing so, these failing states will be clearly called upon to better control their external borders.

Furthermore, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the Schengen acquis, insofar as these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be made at the European level and not on an intergovernmental basis.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to the entirety of the long-term measures considered within the framework of a common migration policy.
It is notably essential to strengthen Frontex, to provide for greater solidarity. I conclude by supporting the states located at external borders.
The situation the Mediterranean has experienced in recent years only highlights a shortcoming of the Schengen Area.

Mr. President, in its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself the objective of making our economy greener and our transport systems more modern.

Certainly, the crisis is economic and financial, but above all, it is a social crisis for our citizens.
Reducing the number of people in precarious situations by twenty million by 2020 requires strong measures involving the various levels of public authority.

We must, more than ever, uphold the commitments made by Europe in 2010, during the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion, and upon the creation of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion, to establish a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must ensure the sustainability and optimization of European funds, and in particular the current support program for the most vulnerable, improve social protection, and support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly, and dependent individuals.
Poverty is a scourge to be combatted at the systemic level, and the time has come to take action to enable the most vulnerable to escape their precariousness.

As rapporteur for the opinion of the development committee, I am pleased that the fisheries committee has taken up the elements contained in our opinion, as it is crucial that the development dimension
should be taken into account in measures aimed at combating illegal fishing at the global level, in the name of policy coherence and close links with development policy.
Indeed, combating illegal fishing requires comprehensive solutions and implementation by all States, including developing nations.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capabilities of states are also taken into account in the actions to be undertaken.
Indeed, one cannot impose the same constraints without supporting measures on developed or developing countries.
Small island states, for example, have very limited capacities.

Therefore, the Union will need to strengthen the financial envelope for the fisheries sector when it concludes agreements in this area with developing countries.

Alternatively, these resources are necessary for developing countries to implement social, economic, and educational policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union, when implementing these measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, promote the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside the beneficiary states receiving assistance.
To adopt a holistic and necessary approach to curbing this scourge that is illegal fishing. Thank you.

We are now finally arriving at the vote on this report, which is extremely important because it allows us to bring up in this hemicycle, to the Commission and the Council, the difficulties and concerns of our fellow citizens.

Petitions concerning the environment are dominant, and waste constitutes a significant concern for our fellow citizens.
This topic must address a societal issue.
We are consuming at a rapid pace.
We are only now beginning to realize that what is not consumed is discarded.
This awareness must be absolutely reinforced among citizens, that is clear.
But this report is also a wake-up call for Member States.
It is still concerning to see that the states appear not to be controlling the situation.
Only six Member States transposed the Waste Framework Directive on time.
The number of complaints received on the subject sometimes demonstrates a lack of transparency in the selection of landfill sites.
Finally, and this is all the more worrying, organized crime appears to be doing as it pleases.
A market of seventy-five billion euros inevitably attracts covetousness.
States must send a strong signal.
It is necessary to increase sanctions against companies that disclose public contracts in order to profit from them.
This report is a wake-up call for states, but the European Commission must also play its part and ensure the proper implementation of waste directives.
It is necessary to make this file visible, but also credible.
If no one plays along, we will continue to waste time and money on verification and counter-verification procedures that risk lasting for years.
Let us heed the message of the petitioners and halt this waste more swiftly.

European citizens must be guaranteed the right to access and rectify personal data concerning them, as well as the right to lodge a judicial appeal in case of violation of their rights.
It is necessary to act to enable European and international standards to coexist and resolve a potential legal conflict detrimental to European citizens.
European legislation alone is not sufficient.
It must articulate and coexist intelligently with international standards, as we can absolve ourselves of our duties and commitments to European citizens.

I believe that taxation is an interesting tool for influencing behavior.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to correct the cost attributed to unsubstantiated allegations regarding the circulation in France of 500 to one million counterfeit biometric passports that are purportedly circulating in our country.
France takes the risks of identity fraud very seriously.
She does not take offenses in this area lightly.
At the initiative of its government, identity theft is a criminal offense punishable by one year of imprisonment and a fine of 15 euros.
The conditions for issuing identity documents have been simplified, which has enabled prefectures to free up additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, in each department, a fraud liaison officer is designated.
Furthermore, the provisions for securing and issuing identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, civil status data provided may be verified between administrative services as much as possible through electronic means in order to limit the risks of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same rigor applies to proof of domicile documentation.
The Ministry of the Interior has embarked on a path towards increased security for proof of address documentation with the inclusion of a barcode.

The standard processing of a title request includes authorized consultation of relevant files, comparison of all documents submitted in previous title requests, and potential authentication of supporting documentation.

The security of title issuance is further ensured by the applicant’s 1 dual appearance, first at the time of application submission and then for title collection, as well as the capture of two digital fingerprints.
And without mentioning the enhanced verification procedures for the renewal of lost and stolen titles, for comparative purposes with the data held by the prefectures. I conclude.

Furthermore, France informs the international cooperation bodies, and notably Interpol. I conclude, Mr. President, that I have nearly completed the process of tracking passports issued, lost, or stolen, so as to prevent their use for fraudulent purposes.
Dear colleagues, France, like the network of the European Union, is committed.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, first of all, an observation: our citizens increasingly wish to find and consume food produced locally and seasonally, notably for reasons of health and quality.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and rapidly to this growing demand.

We must support the establishment of local infrastructure for producers, such as maintaining local abattoirs, which, while ensuring rigorous sanitary controls, enable the development of short local supply chains and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers market their products and raise consumer awareness of them.
Strengthening these direct relationships will allow farmers to retain a greater portion of the added value generated on their farms.

It is necessary to encourage and facilitate direct sales within the farm and to support collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective sales points that allow local consumers access to a wider range of products.

The European Commission must facilitate the emergence, sustainability, and development of direct-to-consumer sales systems such as amAPs in France, which enable nearly 3 farmers to supply sixty families.

Finally, Member States must be able to add further criteria, particularly concerning the size of the holding, the volume of production, or the traditional character of the product, to define local agriculture.

I am pleased that this amending budget concerning the financing of ITER, which was approved by a large majority in the Budget Committee on March 29th last, is before us.
By funding this top-up, we avoid dismissing a strategic project of fundamental research in which the European Union plays a leading role, and we honor our international commitments.
Let us recall that none of the seven partners in the Eurometropolis community has questioned its overall contribution to the project.
Japan, despite the Fukushima disaster, has decided to scrupulously honor its budgetary commitments to ITER.
Without this agreement, hundreds of researchers would have had to suspend their work and the ITER project would have experienced detrimental delays.
Today, a thousand people work for ITER at each dismantling.
From 2015 through 2017, and potentially into 2018, the construction of buildings and the assembly of the machine could require up to four to five personnel at this site.
In conclusion, Mr. President, ITER is a source of pride for Europe and a symbol of our excellence.

The European Union needs a manifesto, a shared political vision regarding the major environmental challenges on the horizon and beyond 2020.

This programme must ensure coherence and articulation between the European Union's environmental strategies and sectoral policies, whether in agriculture,
fishing, research and innovation, health, transportation, regional development, land use planning, and urban policies, naturally.

The stakes are too high, particularly with regard to the efficient use of our resources and the enhancement of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in the sustainable economy and eco-innovation, a source of growth, competitiveness, and employment.

We cannot overlook this environmental education essential for European citizens.
The environmental action program is a policy programming instrument, but it is also a communication tool.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, in the face of the profound transformations our world is subject to today, the Union must reform its Generalized Preference System.
As with any compromise, this one does not deviate from the rule.
While satisfying from a purely commercial perspective, it falls far short of being ideal. We must remember that this regulation is addressed to developing countries.
In developing its new differentiation paradigm, the Commission states its intention to refocus its action in favor of the poorest countries.
It does not appear entirely sustainable at first glance.
To this end, the Commission nevertheless developed a strictly accounting perspective based solely on the criterion of GDP per capita.
One can clearly see the limitations of this approach.
What of numerous developing middle-income countries with undiversified economies and which are vulnerable to climatic hazards?
The agreement reached with the Council does not address this question, and that is why I am calling on my colleagues to vote in favor of the three amendments that will be submitted on this text.
Sir Commissioner, the issue of the availability of public consultations in different languages was, unfortunately, not new to him.

It is, in my opinion, a crucial question, and I have already not only submitted several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally questioned Mr. Barroso in writing.

Indeed, the Commission must comply with the principle of equal access to information for all European citizens, as recalled by the Court of First Instance of the European Communities in its judgment of twenty November two thousand eight.
I was not at all satisfied with the European Commission’s response, which stated that public consultations do not purport to provide a wholly representative picture of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission takes into account the fact that certain positions and viewpoints may be overrepresented to the detriment of others.
This is not an answer.
I question the criteria that would allow for the measurement of an overrepresentation of the European population.
If written consultations are not representative due to English being the sole language available, for example, they fail to achieve their purpose of consulting European citizens.
Thus, the result provides a misleading indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.

If we want to preserve the *consultas secretes* as a tool at the heart of the European Commission's legislative proposals, we must ensure it is democratic, transparent, and equitable for all citizens.
Thus, if the European Commission undertakes written circulation, it must accept its responsibilities and ensure the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
To conclude, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle.

It would also be necessary to incorporate into the analysis excessively short deadlines for submissions and contributions, as well as the limited resources deployed by the Commission to communicate about these consultations, which are unfortunately accessible primarily to insiders. Thank you.
The proposed rule aims to grant the European Commission increased powers to control national budgets and economic policies.
The rules will be stricter, and defaulting states will be subjected by Brussels technocrats to budget cuts and structural reforms in order to restore their financial equilibria.
This enhanced monitoring is referred to as guardianship.
States will be penalized, fined, essentially humiliated. Financial sanctions will be strengthened and more automatic.
Although some amendments aim to prevent austerity measures alone through growth initiatives, your proposals serve only to sweeten the pill.
Growth, as you and I know, is not decreed.
Without consulting the people and with the complicity of Brussels, we permanently lose our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And when, little by little, according to the technique of the Chinese thief, the bureaucratic, technocratic, and totalitarian European state has finished constituting itself, we will have lost our freedom as a people, outright.
Mr. President, without diminishing the importance of the economic choices we must assume, you will allow me to emphasize a remark of a more political nature within the context of this debate.

European discipline must apply to all, without exception, even for the substantial waste that is Luxembourg.

Mr. President, I would first like to commend the determination of the European Commission, and particularly yours, Commissioner, for tirelessly placing the recovery and deepening of the single market at the top of the European agenda.

You recalled, Commissioner, that for over two years now, both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the internal market, to identify the issues and sectors for which more internal market is needed, more internal market for greater growth, greater competitiveness, and more employment.

The European Council, for its part, also eventually signaled the significant importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the single market, the twelve drivers for growth.
But rather than constantly seeking to invent new instruments of growth, we would be better served by working with the toolkit we already possess.

We therefore seize the opportunity of the resolution that will be submitted tomorrow to the vote of our Assembly to send a strong political message to the Member States: greater speed and efficiency in the transposition of directives.

to adopt greater mobilization and engagement in newly opened construction sites. I will cite only one example: the strengthening of worker mobility, greater ease of circulation, and improved traffic flow.

Mr. President, we are currently experiencing a situation with an increase in production of more than 2 and. Simultaneously, industrial manufacturers are lowering prices.

Parliament has already voted on the necessity here of ensuring that the added value is distributed between producers and that farmers are not victims of companies and large retailers.

I ask the Commission today, but also the Council, to reconsider the challenge to production control, but, at the same time, I say very clearly that Member States must clean up their own houses because there are countries that have respected the rules of quotas and others that have not.

There is a dual responsibility for the Commission and the Member States.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, I speak on behalf of Maurice Pongard, rapporteur for the opinion of the Development Committee on the report by Mr. Gallagher.
It seemed important to me to recall that, when wishing to sanction a country practicing unsustainable fishing, it must take into account its level of development.

Indeed, in the name of the principle of policy coherence with development objectives, it is crucial, in my view, that measures adopted in the area of fisheries do not undermine the development plans and strategies implemented by the European Union in these countries.
Mr. Gallagher’s draft report takes up this important idea for our development commission by stipulating that measures should not be unwarranted nor even discriminatory.

I therefore invite the European Commission, when adopting such measures, to respect this principle of policy coherence with development objectives and to duly take into account the level of development and the vulnerability of countries. Thank you.
The third reform of the common fisheries policy must not, once again, be carried out against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these plunderers of the sea, solely responsible for the deteriorating health of stocks as claimed, encompassing all categories of fishing, by environmental organizations and the European Commission.

It is, of course, essential to preserve fish stocks, but it is also necessary to allow our fishermen to live from their activities and to preserve the economic fabric, dynamism, and cultural identity of our coastal regions.
Alternatively, the European executive’s main measures are once again geared towards reducing the number of fishermen in order to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I recall that the French fleet has diminished by more than fifty since nineteen eighty.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the implementation of transferable individual quotas, a guarantee of industrialization and concentration within the sector, or alternatively, a total ban on discharges that professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project likely suits the industrial fleet, but in its current state, it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Establishing a mechanism for information sharing on intergovernmental agreements will therefore enhance transparency in the energy market and thus enable anticipation of energy supply issues.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank Charles Goentz for his excellent report.

We all know here at the European Union that it provides more than half of the total global Official Development Assistance, and yet, as the MDG deadline of 2015 approaches, even if some objectives seem
Having reached this point, we must consider how to improve our assistance, how to make it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must rest on precise, measurable commitments, according to a short- and medium-term timeline.

The economic crisis, climate change, the rise of emerging powers, and land grabbing compel us to define new priorities—priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

Certainly, a European consensus exists, but we must rethink European and international institutional systems regarding environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from bodies that function effectively in decision-making, such as the WTO, for example.
Finally, and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not only charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for ourselves.
It is enough to look at the markets opening up for Europeans in emerging countries: China, Brazil, and India.
2015 will also provide an opportunity to better account for the geostrategic evolution of recent years, as the emerging nations of today were, until recently, still developing countries.
From now on, as indispensable economic powers, these countries must also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at both the European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than a deadline; it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as mere financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both socially and environmentally.

I therefore join here with my colleagues from the other groups and those from the economic and social committee and the regional committee in requesting that 2015 be designated the European Year of Development and, above all, of responsible development.
Mr. President, the agenda for change proposed by the Commission, in my opinion, raises numerous questions, the primary one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission wishes that, from 2014 onwards, the selection of countries in which the European Union will invest its development assistance will be based on the mechanical application of the single criterion of per capita income.
As Mrs. Ashton recalled, these questions are not solely of an accounting nature, but warrant a genuine political debate regarding the definition of our priorities in international cooperation.
Furthermore, this differentiated approach, in my opinion, is not in keeping with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries achieving positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition to more sustainable growth. These countries should not be unduly penalized for having succeeded in ensuring growth through discipline, good governance, and prudent economic policies.
Madam President, Commissioner, let us acknowledge the initiative taken by Jacques Delors twenty years ago, at the very moment the Berlin Wall was falling.
Despite all the progress we have observed since the beginning of our debate, it must be acknowledged that the single act is now synonymous with injustice, inequality, and economic liberalism.
I would like to hear from you, Mr. Barnier, Commissioner, to tell us how we will build together a more equitable Europe, a facilitating Europe, a protective Europe.

There are a number of avenues to consider, and I would like to hear your thoughts on which of these are at the heart of the economic and social crisis as we unfortunately know it: tax harmonization, public services.
wage protections minimum in Europe, establishment of reinforced cooperation, employment-generating, facilitate cross-border collaborations and develop a policy of fair exchange.
Here are, I believe, the challenges facing us twenty years later.
I rely on you, Commissioner, to ensure that we jointly advance this fine policy of European construction.

Mr. President, as a member of the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee, I have closely examined the report by my colleague Regina Bastos concerning the twenty principal concerns of citizens and businesses.
We debated this report, which is also linked to our discussion on the twenty years of the single market.

It has been twenty years already that the free movement of goods, people, services, and capital is supposed to be able to fully exercise itself within our living space, of exchange, of the internal market.

I was particularly interested to note that at the forefront, the concerns expressed by our European fellow citizens include the absence of professional qualifications, and that we must truly be particularly proactive and particularly effective.

This is what our citizens expect—we must genuinely implement, in the very near future, procedures for recognizing their credentials, skills, and professional qualifications that are truly faster, simpler, more efficient, and less costly.
It is a genuine challenge.

As the rapporteur fictive for the EPE group on this subject of modernizing these procedures, I am actively working with the other members of the IMCO Commission to truly address this major challenge of mobility.
Greater mobility, for a greater Europe—that is what our citizens are asking for. Thank you.
Mr. President, the Committee on Petitions has this year acquired the right to be automatically associated with the hearings of European citizens' initiatives.
It is for me the strong signal of the year 2011 for this Commission.
Citizens already had a commission to which they could appeal in cases of rights violations, but this will also be the case when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I hope that the Petitions Committee can thus be increasingly regarded as the preferred interlocutor of citizens within the European Parliament.
This issue of consideration is also reflected in the outcomes of objections raised by the petitions committee.
Too often, we are approached by citizens facing legal quagmires on which we would like to take a stance. But when the issues are European,
Although we maintain that solutions should be European, we remain powerless, as subsidiarity still does not align with European solutions due to a lack of national will.

I will take the difficult example of transnational divorces. The problems are both national and European, when custody or visitation rights extend beyond national borders, those of Germany, for example.
Despite the glaring difficulties faced by many parents of children born of binational unions, we remain, here in Parliament, powerless to act.

My proposal for all European citizens to have the right to a national ombudsman, particularly from Germany, which submits a vast number of petitions, modeled after the French Defender of Rights, has had no effect whatsoever.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, this remains a problematic conciliation between European solutions and national solutions.
In numerous cases, European law appears powerless to meet the expectations of citizens.
The European year of 2013 will need to address citizens’ grievances, the cost notwithstanding, but we require means of action to be.
